revisions.rev: {{Infobox OS | name = FreeDOS | logo = [[Image:Freedosfishlogo.png|250px|The FreeDOS logo]] | screenshot = [[Image:FreeDOS-1.0-LiveCD-Boot.png|250px|]] | caption = FreeDOS booting screen shot | developer = [[Jim Hall (programmer)|Jim Hall]] & The FreeDOS team | kernel_type = [[Monolithic kernel]]{{cite book|last=Villani|first=Pat|authorlink=|title= FreeDOS Kernel |year=1996|publisher= Miller Freeman|location= Emeryville, CA, USA|isbn= 0-87930-436-7}} | supported_platforms = [[x86 architecture|x86]] | ui = DOS [[Command line interface]] | family = [[DOS]] | source_model = [[Free and open source software|Free and open source]] with a few [[closed source]] utils | released = {{release date and age|1994|06|28}} | latest_release_version = 1.0 | latest_release_date = {{release date and age|2006|09|03}} | language = [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]] | working_state = Current | license = [[GNU GPL]] with some [[freeware]] and [[shareware]] licensed utils | website = [http://www.freedos.org/ www.freedos.org] }} '''FreeDOS''' (formerly '''Free-DOS''' and '''PD-DOS''') is an [[operating system]] for [[IBM PC compatible]] computers. FreeDOS is made up of many different, separate programs that act as "packages" to the overall FreeDOS Project. As a member of the [[DOS]] family, it provides mainly disk access through its [[Kernel (computer science)|kernel]], and partial [[memory management]], but no default [[Graphical user interface|GUI]] (although [[OpenGEM]] is listed on the official FreeDOS website). {{As of|2011}} FreeDOS itself was at version 1.0, released on September 3, 2006;{{cite web|url=http://www.freedos.org/|title=Official homepage of FreeDOS|date=|accessdate= 2008-01-02|author= |publisher= FreeDOS}} many of the packages making up FreeDos are updated or added to frequently. FreeDOS supports vintage hardware IBM PC as well as modern ones, in addition to [[embedded computer]]s. Unlike [[MS-DOS]], it is composed of [[free and open source software]], licensed under the terms of the [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL). It does not require license fees or royalties and creation of custom distributions is permitted.{{cite web|url=http://sourceforge.net/projects/freedos/|title=The FreeDOS Project|date=2006-05-21|accessdate=2008-01-02|author=|publisher=SourceForge}} However, in its "util" section, it includes non-GPL software such as [[4DOS]].{{cite web|url=http://www.freedos.org/software/?cat=util|title=FreeDOS Software: util section|date=|accessdate=09-05-26|author=|publisher=The FreeDOS Project}} FreeDOS has a sparsely-populated [[IRC channel]], #freedos, on irc.i7c.org. == History == The FreeDOS [[project]] began June 29, 1994, after [[Microsoft]] announced it would no longer sell or support [[MS-DOS]]. [[Jim Hall (programmer)|Jim Hall]] then posted a manifesto proposing the development of an [[open-source]] replacement.{{cite newsgroup | title = PD-DOS project *announcement* | author = [[Jim Hall (programmer)|Jim Hall]] | date = 1994-06-29 | newsgroup = comp.os.msdos.apps | url = http://groups.google.com/group/comp.os.msdos.apps/browse_thread/thread/a10993e044dc4b35/e1bb36f1f0d1513b?lnk=st&q=&rnum=26#e1bb36f1f0d1513b | accessdate = 2008-06-14}} Within a few weeks, other programmers including [[Pat Villani]] (1954â2011) and [[Tim Norman]] joined the project. A kernel, the [[COMMAND.COM]] [[command line interpreter]] and core utilities were created by pooling code they had written or found available.{{cite web|url=http://www.linuxfordevices.com/c/a/News/The-past-present-and-future-of-the-FreeDOS-Project/|title=The past, present, and future of the FreeDOS Project|date=2002-03-25|accessdate=2008-06-14|author=Hall, Jim}}{{cite web| url=http://www.freedos.org/freedos/about/| date=September 23, 2006| title=History of FreeDOS|first=Jim| last=Hall| publisher=freedos.org| accessdate=2007-05-28}} There have been several official pre-release distributions of FreeDOS before the final FreeDOS 1.0 distribution.{{cite newsgroup |title = Removing old distributions from ibiblio |author = [[Jim Hall (programmer)|Jim Hall]] |date = 2007-10-02 |newsgroup = Freedos-devel | id = | url = http://www.mail-archive.com/freedos-devel@lists.sourceforge.net/msg05988.html | accessdate = 2009-10-07 }} '''GNU/DOS''', a distribution of FreeDOS, was discontinued after version 1.0 was released.{{cite web|url=http://sourceforge.net/projects/gnudos/|title=GNU/DOS|date=2007-03-29|accessdate=2009-01-02|author=|publisher=SourceForge}}{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/GNU-DOS-Project-Discontinued-41470.shtml|title=GNU/DOS Project Discontinued|date=2006-12-02|accessdate=2009-01-02|author=Marinof, Mihai|publisher=Softpedia}} == Distribution == FreeDOS 1.0 is available for download as [[CD-ROM]] images: a base disc that only contains the kernel and basic applications, and a full disc that contains many more applications (games, networking, development, etc.), not available {{As of|2011|11|lc=on}} but with a newer version announced "soon".{{cite web|url=http://www.freedos.org/freedos/files/|title=FreeDOS: Files|date=|accessdate=2011-11-04|author=|publisher=}} Versions of these two discs with source code, which can boot as [[LiveCD]]s, are also available.{{cite web|url=http://www.freedos.org/freedos/files/|title=FreeDOS: Files|date=|accessdate=2009-05-26|author=|publisher=}} === Commercial uses === FreeDOS is used by several companies: * [[Dell]] includes FreeDOS with their [[Dell n Series|n-series]] [[Desktop computer|desktop]]s. The firm has been criticized for making these machines no cheaper, and harder to buy than identical systems with Windows.{{cite web|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/10/06/dell_open_pc/|title=How Dell repels attempts to buy its 'open source' PC|accessdate=2008-01-02|author=Vance, Ashlee|publisher=The Register}} In addition, Dell often only offers FreeDOS systems with features such as dual-core processors, which FreeDOS cannot use (although theoretically a [[DOS extender]] could). * [[HP]] provides FreeDOS as an option in its ''dc5750'' desktops, ''Mini 5101'' [[netbook]]s and ''Probook'' [[laptop]]s.{{cite web|url=http://h18000.www1.hp.com/products/quickspecs/12546_na/12546_na.HTML |title=DC5750 Product Specifications |accessdate=2009-08-01 |date=2008-10-29 |publisher=[[HP]] }}{{cite web|url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Desktops-and-Notebooks/First-Look-at-HPs-LowCost-ProBook-Laptop-Lineup-880043/|title=First Look at HP's Low-Cost ProBook Laptop Lineup |accessdate=2009-03-26|publisher=[[EWeek]]}}{{cite web|url=http://technologizer.com/2009/06/23/hps-mini-5101-netbook-deluxe-with-all-the-trimmings/ |title=HPâs Mini 5101: Netbook Deluxe, With All the Trimmings |accessdate=2009-08-01 |last=McCracken |first=Harry |date=2009-06-23 |publisher=Technologizer }} FreeDOS is also used to create [[bootable]] media for [[Patch (computing)#Application|updating]] the [[BIOS]] [[firmware]].{{cite web|url=http://h20000.www2.hp.com/bizsupport/TechSupport/SoftwareDescription.jsp?lang=en&cc=us&prodTypeId=321957&prodSeriesId=3442832&swItem=ob-88522-1&mode=4&idx=3 |title=FreeDOS Bootable Media |accessdate=2011-01-13 |date=2010-10-25 |publisher=[[HP]] }} * [[ASUS]] uses FreeDOS to let users boot their motherboard driver CDs to create the [[Serial ATA|SATA]] device driver disk (needed for Windows versions before XP SP2).{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} * [[Gibson Research Corporation|GRC]]'s [[SpinRite]] 6, a hard drive maintenance and recovery program, includes FreeDOS.{{cite web|url=http://www.grc.com/sr/spinrite.htm|title=GRC dard drive data recovery software|date=2006-02-02|accessdate=2009-05-16|author=|publisher=Gibson Research Corporation}}{{cite interview|last = Gibson|first = Steve|subjectlink = Steve Gibson (computer programmer)|interviewer = [[Leo Laporte]]|title = |type = |url = http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DjHtJxsVEd4|format = |program = Call for Help|callsign = [[TechTV]]|city = [[Toronto]], [[Canada]]|accessdate = 2009-05-26}} * [[Seagate Technology|Seagate]]'s SeaTools for DOS loads the FreeDOS kernel.{{cite web|url=http://www.seagate.com/www/en-us/support/downloads/seatools/seatooldreg|title=SeaTools for DOS Download|accessdate=2009-03-06|publisher=Seagate}} * [[Intel Corporation|Intel]]'s Solid-State Drive Firmware Update Tool loads the FreeDOS kernel.{{cite web|url= http://downloadcenter.intel.com/detail_desc.aspx?agr=&ProductID=&DwnldID=18363&strOss=&OSFullName=&lang=eng|title=Intel Solid-State Drive Firmware Update Tool boot cd|accessdate=2010-03-25|publisher=Intel}} === Non-commercial uses === FreeDOS is also used in multiple independent projects: * FUZOMA is a FreeDOS-based distribution that can boot from a [[floppy disk]] and converts older computers into educational tools for children.{{cite web|url=http://superkeen.com/peacecorpsweblog/learning-software/|title=FUZOMA Educational Software|accessdate=2009-12-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} * FED-UP is the Floppy Enhanced DivX Universal Player.{{cite web|url=http://membres.multimania.fr/zeroiq/index.php?page=40..FED-UP%20boot%20floppy%20.php|title=Floppy Enhanced DivX Universal Player|accessdate=2009-12-18}} * [[Doscore]] is a FreeDOS-based distribution that can boot from a [[CD]] and has integrated Internet and file-sharing abilities that also features a Graphical User interface internally developed by the team of Finntech and Doscore .{{cite web|url=http://www.doscore.net|title=Doscore homepage}} == Compatibility == {| class="wikitable" align="left" style="font-size:86%" !colspan="4" |FreeDOS Version History |- ! Version ! Status ! Codename ! Date |- | 0.05 | ALPHA | None | January 12, 1998 |- | 0.1 | BETA | Orlando | March 25, 1998 |- | 0.2 | BETA | Marvin | October 28, 1998 |- | 0.3 | BETA | Ventura | April 21, 1999 |- | 0.4 | BETA | Lemur | April 9, 2000 |- | 0.5 | BETA | Lara | August 10, 2000 |- | 0.6 | BETA | Midnite | March 18, 2001 |- | 0.7 | BETA | Spears | September 7, 2001 |- | 0.8 | BETA | Nikita | April 7, 2002 |- | 0.9rc1 | BETA | Methusalem | July, 2003 |- | 0.9rc2 | BETA | None | August 23, 2003 |- | 0.9rc3 | BETA | None | September 27, 2003 |- | 0.9rc4 | BETA | None | February 5, 2004 |- | 0.9rc5 | BETA | None | March 20, 2004 |- | 0.9 | BETA | None | September 28, 2004 |- | 0.9sr1 | BETA | None | November 30, 2004 |- | 0.9sr2 | BETA | None | November 30, 2005 |- | 1.0 | FINAL | None | September 3, 2006 |} ===MS-DOS and Win32 console=== FreeDOS is mostly compatible with MS-DOS. It supports [[COM file|.COM executables]], standard [[DOS executable]]s and [[Borland]]'s 16-bit [[DOS Protected Mode Interface|DPMI]] executables. It is also possible to run [[32-bit]] DPMI executables using [[DOS extender]]s. The operating system has several improvements relative to MS-DOS, mostly involving support of newer standards and technologies that did not exist when Microsoft ended support for MS-DOS, such as [[internationalization]], [[Advanced Power Management]] [[Terminate and Stay Resident|TSR]]s, and integrated [[ASPI]].{{cite web|url=http://www.techworld.com/networking/news/index.cfm?newsid=6783|title=DOS lives! Open source reinvents past|date=2006-09-04|accessdate=2009-05-26|author=Matthew Broersma|publisher=Techworld}} Furthermore, with use of [[HX DOS Extender]], many [[Win32 console]] applications function properly in FreeDOS, as do some [[Graphical user interface|GUI]] programs, like [[QEMU]] and [[Bochs]].{{cite web|url=http://www.japheth.de/HX.html|title=HX DOS Extender|date=|accessdate=2009-01-02|author=japheth|publisher=}} ===Windows 1.0 to 3.xx=== FreeDOS is able to run [[Microsoft Windows]] [[Microsoft Windows 1.0|1.0]] and [[Microsoft Windows 2.0|2.0]] releases. Windows [[Windows 3.0|3.x]] releases, which had support for [[Intel 80386|i386]] processors, can be run in ''[[386 Enhanced Mode]]'' since FreeDOS kernel build 2037. ===Windows 9x and Windows Millennium Edition === [[Windows 95]], [[Windows 98|98]] and [[Windows Me|Me]] use a stripped down version of MS-DOS as a [[bootloader]]. FreeDOS cannot be used as a replacement bootloader; however, it can be installed and used beside these systems using a [[boot manager]] program, such as the "METAKERN" included with FreeDOS. Problems running Windows result from Microsoft's [[AARD code|efforts to prevent]] their products running on non-Microsoft DOS implementations.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/600488.stm|title=Caldera vs Microsoft - the settlement|date=2000-01-13|accessdate=2009-01-02|author=Lea, Graham|publisher=BBC News}} ===Windows NT/2000/XP/2003/Vista/2008/7/2008 R2 and ReactOS === [[Windows NT]]-based operating systems, including [[Windows 2000]], [[Windows XP|XP]], [[Windows 2003|2003]], [[Windows Vista|Vista]], [[Windows 2008|2008]], [[Windows 7|7]] and [[Windows 2008 R2|2008 R2]] do not make use of [[MS-DOS]] as a core component of the system. These systems can make use of the [[File Allocation Table|FAT]] file systems, which are used by MS-DOS and earlier versions of [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]; however, they typically use the [[NTFS]] ([[Windows NT|NT]] File System) by default. FreeDOS can coexist on these systems on a separate partition on NTFS systems, or on the same partition on FAT systems. The FreeDOS [[Kernel (computer science)|kernel]] can be booted by adding it to the [[NTLDR|Windows NT Boot Loader]] configuration file, '''boot.ini''', or '''freeldr.ini''' for [[ReactOS]]. ===File systems=== [[Image:Fdedit.png|thumb|250px|A screenshot of FreeDOS's default text editor. It is a clone of the [[MS-DOS Editor]] with added features.]] [[FAT32]] is fully supported and can be booted from. Depending on the [[BIOS]] used, up to four [[Logical block addressing|LBA]] hard disks up to 128 GB, or 2 TB, in size are supported. There has been little testing with large disks, and some BIOSes support LBA but produce errors on disks larger than 32 GB; a driver such as [[OnTrack]] or [[EZ-Drive]] resolves this problem. FreeDOS can also be used with a driver called ''DOSLFN'', which supports long file names (see [[File Allocation Table|VFAT]]), but most old programs do not support long file names even if the driver is loaded. There is no planned support for [[NTFS]] or [[ext2]], but there are several external third-party drivers available for that purpose. To access ext2fs, [[LTOOLS]] (counterpart to [[Mtools|MTOOLS]]) can be used to copy data to and from ext2fs drives. NTFS support is provided by software such as [[NTFSDOS]] and NTFS4DOS.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} ===Universal Serial Bus=== {{As of|2011}} there was no [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] driver support inside the FreeDOS project, but many modern motherboards contain BIOS settings for "Legacy USB" support which allow USB devices to be used in operating systems that lack support for them (such as FreeDOS). This applies to keyboards and mice; some BIOSes support storage devices. Some external DOS USB drivers (such as DUSE, USBASPI and USBMASS) for storage devices work with some effort. There is also DOSUSB which offers an API and supports storage devices, printers and serial adapters. An alternative to running DOS programs with USB devices is to use virtualisation software, such as [[DOSBox]], which recognizes USB devices from the host operating system to act as if they were "legacy port" devices (e.g. [[joystick]]s with [[game port]]s, printers with [[parallel port]]s, and [[USB flash drive]]s would act as if they were a hard drive for DOS), but this requires an OS with a GUI.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} == Features == * Easy [[Multi boot|multiboot]] with Windows 9x and NT * [[File Allocation Table#FAT32|FAT32]] file system and large disk support ([[Logical block addressing|LBA]]) * [[Long filename]] support via DOSLFN driver * XDMA & XDVD — [[Parallel ATA#UDMA and ATA-4|UDMA]] driver for hard discs and [[DVD player]]s * LBACACHE — disk cache * Memory Managers: JEMM386 ([[Extended memory#eXtended Memory Specification (XMS)|XMS]], [[Expanded memory|EMS]], etc.) ** Possibility of writing 32-bit protected mode drivers (JLMs=Jemm Loadable Module) * SHSUCDX ([[MSCDEX]] replacement) and [[CD-ROM]] driver (XCDROM) * CUTEMOUSE — Mouse driver with scroll wheel support * FDAPM — [[Advanced Power Management|APM]] info/control/suspend/poweroff, [[Advanced Configuration and Power Interface|ACPI]] throttle, [[HLT]] energy saving * [[MPXPLAY]] — media player for mp3, ogg, wmv, with built-in [[AC'97]] and [[Sound Blaster 16|SB16]] drivers; has a user interface * 7ZIP, INFO-ZIP, zip, unzip — modern archivers * EDIT / SETEDIT — multi window [[text editor]]s * HTMLHELP — help viewer, can read help directly from a zip file * PG — powerful text viewer (similar to V. D. Buerg's LIST) * Many text mode programs ported from Linux thanks to DJGPP * FreeCOM — command line, supports [[Command line completion|file completion]] * [[4DOS]] can be installed, which is an enhanced command line. * GRAPHICS — greyscale [[Print screen|hardcopy]] on [[ESC/P]], [[Printer Command Language|HP PCL]] and [[PostScript]] printers * Arachne — graphical web browser and e-mail client * Fdupdate — update installer * BitTorrent client * [[Anti-virus]] / Virus scanner{{cite web|title=SourceForge.net: freedos|url=http://sourceforge.net/apps/mediawiki/freedos/index.php?title=Main_Page#Features}} 090911 sourceforge.net ==Technical details== === Booting === FreeDOS can be booted from a [[hard drive]], [[live CD]], [[USB flash drive]] or [[floppy disk]].{{cite web|url=http://www.linfo.org/freedos_floppy.html|title=How to Create a Bootable FreeDOS Floppy Disk|date=2005-07-19|accessdate=2008-08-04|author=|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://ben.franske.com/blogs/2007/08/21/booting_dos_from_a_usb_flash_drive|title=Booting DOS from a USB flash drive|date= 2007-08-21|accessdate= 2008-08-04|author=Franske, Ben |publisher=}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|url=http://genetikayos.livejournal.com/43998.html|title=FreeDOS on a USB Flash Drive|date=2005-12-19|accessdate=2008-08-04|author=genetikayos|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.freedos.org/freedos/files/|title=FreeDOS Files|date=|accessdate=2008-08-04|author=|publisher=FreeDOS}} It can also be run using [[Platform virtualization|virtualization]] software like [[Microsoft Virtual PC|Virtual PC]] and [[VirtualBox]] or [[emulator|emulation]] software like [[Bochs]] and [[QEMU]]. To use the Windows Boot Menu the following line can be added to [[BOOT.INI|C:\BOOT.INI]]:{{cite web|url=http://marc.herbert.free.fr/linux/freedos_no_removable.html|title=Install FreeDOS without any CD, floppy, USB-key, nor any other removable media|date=2004-10-01|accessdate=2009-05-26|author=Marc Herbert|publisher=}} C:\FDOSBOOT.BIN="FreeDOS" To boot using [[GRUB]] something similar to the following can be added to menu.lst: title FreeDOS # Anything you want root hd(x,y) # x = device and y = partition on which FreeDOS resides chainloader /kernel.sys # Boots FreeDOS's bootloader === Memory management === The FreeCOM shell, FreeDOS's version of [[COMMAND.COM]], can move portions of itself into [[extended memory]] freeing up large portions of [[conventional memory]], up to 620 kB. This is useful for DOS programs which only use conventional memory. The [[HIMEM]] and [[EMM386]] memory management programs included with FreeDOS provide [[extended memory]] (XMS) and [[expanded memory]] (EMS) for old real mode software, EMM386 also supports [[Virtual Control Program Interface|VCPI]], which allows [[DOS Protected Mode Interface|DPMI]] kernels and DOS extenders to coexist with it. FreeDOS also contains an [[UDMA]] driver for faster disk access, which is also compatible with other DOS versions. The LBAcache disk cache stores recently accessed disk data in XMS for faster access and less direct disk access.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} == See also == {{Portal|Free software}} *[[Arachne (web browser)|Arachne]] â A DOS-based [[Web browser|browser]] included with FreeDOS *[[Command Prompt]] *[[DOSEMU]] *[[DOSBox]] *[[FreeRTOS]] *[[GRUB]] *[[ReactOS]] *[[WinImage]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons|FreeDOS}} *[http://www.freedos.org/ FreeDOS Homepage (official)] *[http://freedos.sourceforge.net FreeDOS Homepage (SourceForge)] *[http://fd-doc.sourceforge.net/ FD-DOC FreeDOS Documentation Project] *[http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/micro/pc-stuff/freedos/files/distributions/1.0/ Official Download - FreeDOS 1.0] *[http://www.linfo.org/freedos_commands.html Summary of FreeDOS Commands] *[http://help.fdos.org/ FreeDOS help (commands and usage)] *[http://www-jpc.physics.ox.ac.uk/ Virtual Machine in Java with FreeDOS] *[http://www.linfo.org/freedos_floppy.html How to Create a BootableFreeDOS Floppy Disk] *[http://www.nomdo.dds.nl/opendos.htm FreeDOS bootdisk with several DOS utilities] *[http://genetikayos.livejournal.com/43998.html FreeDOS on a USB Flash Drive] *[http://marc.herbert.free.fr/linux/freedos_no_removable.html Install FreeDOS without any removable media]. *[http://www.ofgsoftware.com/web/virtualizacion/virtualpc2007/freedos/1.0/freedos-1.0.html Virtual Machine for Microsoft Virtual PC 2007 with FreeDOS 1.0 O.S.] {{es icon}} {{FLOSS}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Freedos}} [[Category:Microcomputer software]] [[Category:Disk operating systems]] [[Category:DOS issues]] [[Category:Floppy disk-based operating systems]] [[Category:Free software operating systems]] [[Category:Embedded operating systems]] [[ar:ÙØ±Ù Ø¯ÙØ³]] [[cs:FreeDOS]] [[da:FreeDOS]] [[de:FreeDOS]] [[es:FreeDOS]] [[fr:FreeDOS]] [[ko:íë¦¬ëì¤]] [[it:FreeDOS]] [[lv:FreeDOS]] [[lt:FreeDOS]] [[nl:FreeDOS]] [[ja:FreeDOS]] [[pl:FreeDOS]] [[pt:FreeDOS]] [[ro:FreeDOS]] [[ru:FreeDOS]] [[simple:FreeDOS]] [[sk:FreeDOS]] [[fi:FreeDOS]] [[sv:FreeDOS]] [[tr:FreeDOS]] [[uk:FreeDOS]] [[yo:FreeDOS]] [[zh:FreeDOS]]
